claims.text: In 2008, prices in Zimbabwe doubled every 24 hours due to inflation.
claims.context: Historical example of extreme inflation in Zimbabwe.

claims.text: In 2008, prices in Zimbabwe doubled every 24 hours due to inflation.
claims.context: Historical example of extreme inflation in Zimbabwe.

claim_reports.claim_text: In 2008, prices in Zimbabwe doubled every 24 hours due to inflation.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that in 2008, prices in Zimbabwe doubled approximately every 24 hours due to hyperinflation. Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that during this period, inflation rates were extraordinarily high, with estimates indicating prices effectively doubling daily.

supports.title: Zimbabwe: Inflation at 6.5 quindecillion novemdecillion percent
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during the hyperinflation period in Zimbabwe, prices were indeed doubling approximately every 24.7 hours, which supports the claim about rapid price increases due to inflation.
supports.snippet: ... inflation rate at around 6.5 quindecillion novemdecillion percent - 65 followed by 107 zeros. "Prices double every 24.7 hours," he noted.

supports.title: [PDF] On the Measurement of Zimbabwe's Hyperinflation - Cato Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during the peak of hyperinflation in Zimbabwe in 2008, inflation rates were extraordinarily high, with estimates suggesting month-on-month inflation of 79.6 billion percent, which implies that prices were indeed doubling at an alarming rate, consistent with the claim.
supports.snippet: Zimbabwe first breached the hyperinflation benchmark in March 2007 (Table 1). After falling below the 50 percent threshold in July, August, and September 2007, ...

supports.title: Hyper Inflation in Zimbabwe - Economics Help
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during the height of hyperinflation in Zimbabwe from 2008 to 2009, prices were effectively doubling every day, which aligns with the claim about prices doubling every 24 hours due to inflation.
supports.snippet: That is effectively a daily inflation rate of 98.0. Roughly every day, prices would double. It was also a time of real hardship and poverty, ...

supports.title: Zimbabwe Hyperinflates Again, Entering the Record Books For A ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during the height of hyperinflation in Zimbabwe in 2008, prices were increasing at an extraordinary rate, with estimates of month-on-month inflation reaching 79.6 billion percent, suggesting that prices could indeed have doubled every 24 hours.
supports.snippet: Zimbabwe's annual inflation rate peaked in November 2008, reaching 89.7 sextillion (10^21) percent. Well, Zimbabwe is experiencing ...

supports.title: Hyperinflation in Zimbabwe - Wikipedia
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during the height of hyperinflation in Zimbabwe in 2008, prices were increasing at an extraordinary rate, with estimates of inflation reaching 79.6 billion percent month-on-month, suggesting that prices could indeed have doubled every 24 hours.
supports.snippet: In 2008, the inflation rate accelerated dramatically, from a rate in January of over 100,000% to an estimated rate of over 1,000,000% by May, and nearly 250, ...

transcript_data.text: [Music] when McDonald's launched the Big Mac in 1967 it cost just 45 but the same Big Mac now cost $3.99 why the answer is inflation to see how fast prices are rising everything from the price of a leg wax to the cost of a bottle of whiskey are closely monitored by statistical bureaus these changes in prices are entered into a calculator and out comes one single percentage number the rate of inflation and this number helps government set welfare payments and helps you decide how much to ask your boss for a pay rise in a stable economy prices usually go up steadily over time by 1 or 2% a year but sometimes things get out of hand in 2008 prices in Zimbabwe doubled every 24 hours the government printed more and more money before long everyone was a trillionaire things got so bad that the country ran out of paper to print all the bank notes once an inflationary spiral like this begins it's almost impossible to get out of and governments must either devalue their currency or ditch it all together this is what happened in Germany in the 1920s so is inflation bad not so fast a small amount of inflation is usually seen as a good thing it helps keep an economy growing and it also staves off the threat of deflation and a bit of inflation is good news if you're in debt just ask anyone who took out a mortgage on a low interest rate before a property boom but it's bad news for Savers just as inflation eats into debt it also eats into savings 00 stashed in your piggy bank will buy you less in 5 years time than it will today if your income isn't keeping up with prices you're getting poorer for one of the most important Concepts in economics it's also one of the simplest inflation is just the average rate that prices are rising
